EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



This EPA RMP was prepared in accordance with the requirements of the Clean Air Act ? 112(r), OSHA 29 CFR ? 1910.119, and U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) at 40 CFR ?68. The OSHA PSM and EPA Subpart D RMP standards are applicable to operations at this Facility.  The electronic RMP summarizes the policies and procedures implemented by the Facility to minimize the likelihood of an accident. The electronic RMP also summarizes the actions that the Facility has taken to ensure that a response to a release will be implemented in a proper and timely manner.



PURPOSE FOR UPDATING RMP



Helena Agri-Enterprises, LLC (Helena) is resubmitting the EPA RMP to reflect changes in the overall program management at this Facility.  Helena recently acquired this Facility and has completed the transition from the prior owner PSM/RMP program to the Helena PSM/RMP program.   



It is important to note that the maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia that is stored and handled at the Facility is 284,685 lbs, and the maximum quantity of aqua ammonia that is stored and handled at this Facility is 61,068 lbs (i.e. anhydrous ammonia equivalent).  The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia is the sum of two stationary pressure vessels (i.e. 279,830 lbs or 139,915 lbs each), 14 cylinders (i.e. 2,155 lbs) and 3 TONNERS (i.e. 2,700 lbs).  The maximum quantity of aqua ammonia is the sum of one AST containing 29% anhydrous ammonia equivalent (i.e. 31,234 lbs) and one AST containing 23% anhydrous ammonia equivalent (i.e. 29,835 lbs).



Although the maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia that is stored and handled at the Facility is 284,685 lbs, the total quantity reported in this EPA RMP Report is 564,515 lbs.  The reason for this is because a single anhydrous ammonia pressure vessel (i.e. 139,915 lbs) is counted two more times to account for the Aqua Ammonia Blending and APP Blending processes that are connected to one of the stationary pressure vessels.  Although the

maximum quantity of aqua ammonia that is stored and handled at this Facility is 61,068 lbs, the total quantity reported in this EPA RMP Report is 90,903 lbs.  The reason for this is because the maximum quantity of 29% and 23% anhydrous ammonia equivalent (i.e. 61,068 lbs) is accounted for in the Aqua Ammonia Storage & Handling Process and the maximum quantity of the 23% anhydrous ammonia equivalent (i.e. 29,835 lbs) is counted one more time to account for the Base Blending process that is connected to the 23% AST.



FACILITY



The operations at this Facility consist of chemical storage and handling, blending, retail sale and distribution.  Two chemicals (i.e. anhydrous ammonia and aqua ammonia greater than 20% ammonia concentration) are stored and handled at quantities that exceed the regulatory threshold quantity.  Covered processes operated at this Facility include:



o Covered Process 1: NH3 Storage and Handling

o Covered Process 2: Aqua Ammonia Blending

o Covered Process 3: Aqua Ammonia Storage and Handling

o Covered Process 4: Ammonium Polyphosphate (APP) Blending

o Covered Process 5: Base Blending



OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS



Worst case and alternative case consequence analyses were completed for all five (5) covered processes.  The worst case scenario release assumed that all the contents in the largest single vessel were released. For the anhydrous ammonia (i.e. representing Covered Processes 1, 2, and 4), the worst case release was modeled as if a 30,000-gallon anhydrous ammonia pressure vessel was punctured on the side at the ground level and the resulting release being a ground level horizontal jet at the maximum temperature. For the aqua ammonia, two releases were modeled. One worst case release scenario assumes that a 16,900-gallon aqua ammonia (29%) AST failed and instantaneously spills the content into an area with secondary containment resulting in a release being evaporation at the maximum temperature. The other worst case release scen

ario assumes that a 20,000-gallon aqua ammonia (23%) AST failed and instantaneously spills the content into an area with secondary containment resulting in a release being evaporation at the maximum temperature.



The alternative (or more likely to occur) scenario for anhydrous ammonia assumes a release of anhydrous ammonia due to a 2-inch transfer hose failure during a loading or unloading procedure associated with Covered Processes 1, 2, and 4.  Mitigation by engineering and administrative controls is considered in these scenarios.  The alternative scenario for aqua ammonia (29%) assumes a release of aqua ammonia due to a 3-inch transfer hose failure during an unloading procedure associated with Covered Process 3.  The alternative scenario for aqua ammonia (23%) assumes a release of aqua ammonia due to a 4-inch HDPE process pipe failure during an unloading procedure associated with Covered Process 5.  Mitigation by engineering and administrative controls is considered in these scenarios.



ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM

The Operations Manager implements the risk management planning process at this Facility. The Operations Manager is assisted by other trained personnel as directed. The Operations Manager is responsible for ensuring that its employees are properly trained in the implementation of the Program 2 and 3 Accident Prevention Program elements as related to their responsibilities.  The accident prevention program elements addressed in the PSM/RMP combined program includes: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, Compliance Audits,and Trade Secrets.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



This is a non-responding Facility. The Facility has coordinated emergency response activities with its local emergency response agency and local fire departme

nt. 



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place, in the past five (5) years because of the ammonia operations at this Facility.



CONCLUSION



The Facility complies with the requirements of the Clean Air Act, Section 112(r). The PSM/RMP will be updated as the Facility adds, deletes, or changes processes. 



NOTE: Sections 4, 5, and 6 of EPA's RMP Submit Program are not applicable to the Facility.
